titleStmt.title: Advice given unto the states of of [sic] the Lovv-Countries obedient & faithfull to his Maiesty of Spaine, upon occasion of the letters written by Count Henry Vanden Bergh the 18. day of Iune 1632. to her Highnesse the Archdutchesse, and the estates in those dominions. As also unto the declaration made by him concerning his discontent received, being all fully answered and found to be unjust and unreasonable. If the reader please to compare them together, you shall find Henry of the Bergh his letters and declaration, printed in our aviso of Iune, the 30. Numb. 31. and Iuly 6. Numb. 32. Translated out of the French coppy.

titleStmt.title: Advice given unto the states of of [sic] the Lovv-Countries obedient & faithfull to his Maiesty of Spaine, upon occasion of the letters written by Count Henry Vanden Bergh the 18. day of Iune 1632. to her Highnesse the Archdutchesse, and the estates in those dominions. As also unto the declaration made by him concerning his discontent received, being all fully answered and found to be unjust and unreasonable. If the reader please to compare them together, you shall find Henry of the Bergh his letters and declaration, printed in our aviso of Iune, the 30. Numb. 31. and Iuly 6. Numb. 32. Translated out of the French coppy.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Augu≈øt. 3. Numb. 38.

ADVICE GIVEN VNTO THE STATES OF of the Low-Countries, obedient & faithfull to his Maie≈øty of Spaine, upon occa≈øion of the Letters written by Count Henry Vanden Bergh the 18. day of Iune 1632. to her Highne≈ø≈øe the Archdutche≈ø≈øe, and the E≈øtates in tho≈øe Dominions.
As al≈øo unto the declaration made by him concerning his di≈øcontent received, being all fully an≈øwered and found to be unju≈øt and unrea≈øonable.
If the Reader plea≈øe to compare them together, you ≈øhall find Henry of the Bergh his Letters and Declaration, Printed in our Avi≈øo of Iune, the 30. Numb. 31. and Iuly 6. Numb. 32.

p.hi: Tran≈ølated out of the French Coppy.

div.p: LONDON, Printed by B. A. and T. F. for Nathaniel Butter, and Nicholas Bourne. 1632.

THere is nothing that makes men more commendable before the face of Heauen and Earth, in compari≈øon of true fidelity towards God and their Prince. It is a Primitive vertue which is borne with vs, and ought not to die but with vs without prejudice or wrong to any forraine Nations, it may bee averr'd with preeminence of honour, that there is not any place or Nation, where the Divine wor≈øhip is more religiou≈øly ob≈øerved, the Churches better maintayned and ≈øerved, the Cleargy more exemplary, the Nobility more pious, the people more devout and ob≈øervant in religious duties, than in tho≈øe Provinces of the Low-countries which are ≈øubject and obedient to his Maje≈øty. M ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ tru ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶
Their Temples are in reputation, and in effect to be numbred, and e≈øteemed among≈øt the faire≈øt, and mo≈øt adorned and beautified of all Chri≈øtendome, and the Doctrine of their Prelates in ≈øingular e≈øteeme with the Church of Rome. As concerning the fidelity due unto their Prince, N ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ do ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶
the ≈øame is immoveable and con≈øtant, & hath beene ≈øo acknowledged and tryed by the continuance and pro≈øecution of many ≈øucceeding yeares, yea ≈øuch, that maugre all the power, devices, and ≈øtratagems of the enemie, and di≈øcontented braines, the ≈øame will ≈øtill ≈øub≈øi≈øt in integrity and true obedience.

Wee are under a King the be≈øt that ever bore Crowne in many ages, the mo≈øt pious, and be≈øt affectioned unto his ≈øul ≈øtitutes and ≈øuch as are in authority under him. At this day when Piety & Religion are ≈øo lively oppo≈øed & ≈øet? upon in his Per≈øon and States by impiety and here≈øie, when God and our Prince are both a≈ø≈øaulted at once, whi ‚Ä¢ e every man is now putting to his helping hand in the Ship untill the tempe≈øt be overpa≈øt, you will not (I a≈ø≈øure my ≈øelfe) wonder if among a multitude and infinite number of good men, you ≈øhall find one wicked faithle≈ø≈øe ≈øervant, who turnes his backe to his Ma≈øter, and ki≈ø≈øing him betrayes him, wonder not I ≈øay, if among ≈øo many faithfull ones you meet with one who under pretence of a Patriot and faithfull ≈øupporter of the Countryes, opens a way to ea≈øement.

Our enemies are ≈øo much the more dangerous, by how much more they doe flatter vs. And as the promi≈øe of liberty of con≈øcience is nothing el≈øe but an Introduction of here≈øie: So is the other of publike liberty tendered by the hand of a di≈øloyall one, nothing el≈øe but a deceitfull bayte to replunge our Provinces into the fore-pa≈ø≈øed calamities, out of which the mercy of the Omnipotent hath delivered and brought vs forth. Our ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe (GOD bee ble≈øsed) is not mixed with any bitterne≈ø≈øe, our Sacrifices are not intertu ‚Ä¢ bed or troubled, our lives pa≈ø≈øe along in tranquility, and under the manifold ble≈ø≈øings of Heaven, under the example and government of a Prince≈ø≈øe mo≈øt devout and debonayre, and hope and expectation of a young Prince of Royall race. What is there now wanting to the height of our happine≈ø≈øe, but the accompli≈øhment of a Peace, which cannot be with-held from us, if wee make but ≈øome tryall and proofe worthy of our zeale and good will? We can doe much, if wee have but the will: onely let us have this care, that the want of courage turne not to our reproach & ≈øhame, ≈øince that our dome≈øticke enemies are di≈øcryed & brought to light, tho≈øe without ≈øhalbe inferiour to us. Our dome≈øticke enemies are ≈øuch, who under colour and pretence of ray≈øing up the publike liberty, labour and endeavour to de≈øtroy it by inovation, and bury the ≈øame in their owne ambitious engro≈ø≈øing. And who having no other Religion but that of their ambition and of their owne intere≈øt, doe neverthele≈ø≈øe make profe≈ø≈øion of being very good Catholickes.

The wor≈øt cau≈øe that ever was in the world wanted not ≈øome pretence or other. There is nothing ≈øo like unto an Angell of light as a Daemon or Devill, nothing doth ≈øo counterfeyte, and appeare like unto the truth as fal≈øhood & a lye. You have (my Lords) ≈øeene the ridiculous pretences of Count Henry de Bergh in tho≈øe Letters which hee hath ≈øent to her highne≈ø≈øe, to the States of the Countrey, and the declaration which he made to ≈øollicite the fidelity of ≈øoldiers and men of honour. You have ≈øeene I ≈øay, his foundation without foundation, upon the which he grounds his perver≈øe intentions. But the di≈ølike and di≈øta≈øt which you have taken again≈øt his proceedings hath beene ≈øuch, and your loyalty and fidelity ≈øo commendable, that even to convince his felony, you have (with an
extraordinary affection, & love to the good of the Countrey) contributed unto the Prince farre greater ayde and helpe than formerly you had done. Moreover it is nece≈ø≈øary that be≈øides you, the world be ≈øatisfied, which oftentimes doth judge by the outward appearance, not knowing the truth of things, and that the ≈øame may ≈øee the truth di≈øcovered, le≈øt men be abu≈øed by the cunning ≈ølights and pretences where withall he hides the gro≈ø≈øene≈ø≈øe and ba≈øene≈ø≈øe of his trea≈øon. He begins his letter written to her highne≈ø≈øe with in≈øupportable and boldne≈ø≈øe without mea≈øure, pre≈øenting mo≈øt traytour-like bread in one hand, and a flinty ≈øtone in the other. He expo≈øeth his wicked de≈øignes with all ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion. Never I am ≈øure, was there any rebellion declared with more ≈øhamele≈øne≈ø≈øe and impudency. After this his fayned Ceremony and complement, he complaineth, that the Souldiers were withdrawne from his government, to the end that they might make him be the cau≈øe of their de≈øtruction. It is lawfull for a man to make his complaint but not perfidious. That which he ≈øayes is not truth, and the Letters of the Marqui≈øe De Sancte Croes doe te≈øtifie as much for he required no men from him, but onely beacu≈øe he judged that the enemy would attempt nothing on that ≈øide, leaving all to his owne choi≈øe and de≈øiring him to ≈øee the Bridge well guarded and provided before Venlo, to ≈øuffer the troupes to pa≈ø≈øe over ≈øafely which ≈øhould be ≈øeat to relieve the ≈øame. And put the ca≈øe, that which he affirmeth were true, if hee had beene well minded, and his intention good, he ought to have defended her government to the la≈øt man, and have kept him≈øelfe in the City of Gelder which is a ≈øtrong place, (as he had promi≈øed by Letters to her highne≈ø≈øe, and allowing that Venlo was able to be held) & therein have imitated the genero≈øity of his Brother Count Frederick, who in the yeare 1597. defended him≈øelfe within the City Lingen, even to the extreamity, with onely three Companies of foote and one of Hor≈øe. But this, two dayes before the enemie did come before Venlo, called the Magi≈øtrates and told them, that the city would ≈øoon be be≈øieged, & to take away the courage from the Citizens demon≈øtrated unto them the ≈ømall appearance and hope he had of defending the ≈øame. Wherefore hee excu≈øed him≈øelfe from protecting of them, nay and be≈øides this being Governour of that Province, ≈øaid he had other places to guard & looke to,
neverthele≈ø≈øe he pre≈øently made ha≈øt unto the City Gelder, from whence he departed pre≈øently accompanied onely with one ≈øervant, or Companion, & betooke him≈øelfe to Liege, there to put in execution the perfidiou≈øne≈ø≈øe which he had plodded a long time.

As for his ≈øervice of forty yeares, which he mentions: Tis true, in the beginning they were con≈øiderable, and of ≈øome worth when his brother (who≈øe death he doth alleadge) did animate him by their good and valerous examples. But ever ≈øince, from the yeare 1606 that he defended the City Groll with expectation of reliefe by the Marqui≈øe Spinola who came time enough to re≈øcue him, his ≈øervices have not beene ≈øo remarkeable nor of ≈øuch moment, and moreover they have beene recompenced an hundred fold with dignities and titles, gifts, and honourable charges, and exce≈ø≈øive ≈øummes of Money.

As for the ill government of the Countryes, and the progre≈øse of our enemies, that proceeds from nothing el≈øe but from the manifold treacheries, and the to too much confidence and tru≈øt which our Princes have in his per≈øon, having with a fatherly and favourable affection which they bare unto their ≈øervants, indured a long time his di≈øcontentments, and greevances, which in time by little and little, and more and more are ≈øtill degenerated unto this action the mo≈øt ba≈øe and ignoble that ever could bee returned with reproach unto a rea≈øonable Soule, manife≈øted in the≈øe two branches, ing ‚Ä¢ atitude, and revolt.

One of the fir≈øt te≈øtimonies of his di≈øloyall and evill will which he cunningly concealed, was ob≈øerved at Bergen on Zoom in the yeare 1622. for then and here having received command reiterated by her Highne≈øse, to conduct the Marqui≈øe Spinola with all diligence unto the Army which he than had on the Rhyne, hee made a thou≈øand excu≈øes to prolong the time, and ≈øtay him or keepe him backe untill the want of reliefe cau≈øed us to ray≈øe the ≈øiege. And it was told the Marqui≈øe than, (who was in travaile with impatiency, during this delay) by the Lieutenant of the Artillery, Wyngart by name, that he would loo≈øe his head, if Count Henry de Bergh (whom he had knowne by long experience) did arriue, before the occa≈øion ≈øhould be let ≈ølip.

He thought to have played the ≈øame prancke two yeares after,
in like manuer to divert the ≈øiege of Breda, making profer of an enterpri≈øe upon Raven≈øteyn, afterward upon the Grave, and la≈øtly upon the Ca≈øtle of Genepe. The cunning Letters which after his ≈øubtile manner he wrote full of excu≈øes, have ≈øufficiently di≈øcovered what was his de≈øigne. They are printed at large, in the hi≈øtory of the ≈øiege of Breda, compo≈øed and ≈øet forth by Father Hermanus Hugo.

The confidence which her Highne≈ø≈øe had euer ≈øince in his fidelity for the releeuing of Groll. In the yeare 1627. was the cau≈øe why wee lo≈øt that City. For being there was a difference ri≈øen betweene two Mai≈øters of the Campe, for the vantguard, being of different Nations, hee in≈øtead that hee ≈øhould haue rid them out of the Field, and done as it befitted him for his Maie≈øties ≈øervice, hee coun≈øels the one not to yeild to the other, by that meanes in the meane time, to prevent them both from defeating a Convoy which ea≈øed and refre≈øhed the Enemie, for want of which Convoy the Enemie mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øity haue rai≈øed the ≈øiege. Hee was put to his excu≈øe, and „Äà‚óä„Äâ quitted becau≈øe his authority was not great enough for the deciding the preeminence of Nations, But let vs ≈øee, if hee hath better be haued him≈øelfe when hee had receiued more authority. The City named Shortogenbo≈øch, was be≈øieged by the Prince of Orange in the yeare of our Lord 1629. Wee than prai≈øed God, becau≈øe the Enemie was fallen before a City which was able to defend it ≈øelfe and hold out vntill releife ≈øhould come. Her Highne≈ø≈øe at that time v≈øed ≈øo much diligence, that in few dayes wee had a mo≈øt flouri≈øhing Army on Foote and able to make a ≈øtrong a≈ø≈øault. There was onely que≈øtion made, who ≈øhould command the ≈øame, the Marquis Spinola than being ab≈øent. In the end this was the re≈øolution that Count Henry de Bergh ≈øhould haue the honour, and to this end hee was ≈øent for by her Highne≈ø≈øe. No ≈øooner was hee come to Bruxels, but hee began to propound an hundred difficulties one after another, and frame excu≈øes, to the end that the Enemie might gaine the more time to fortifie them≈øelues. In the≈øe extremicies, and by rea≈øon of the confidence which wee had in him, and partly by rea≈øon of his experience nothing was denied him which hee demanded. Many dayes pa≈ø≈øed in the≈øe entermedlings, but in the end hee
goes to Field, and was by the way (≈øo great ha≈øt he made) from the 3. of June to the 27. and than hee found that the be≈øieged had not yet lo≈øt one Inch of ground of all their outworkes, although the quarters of the Enemie were in good rea≈øonable defence. The advice of the mo≈øt part of the Colonels was to open Trench again≈øt trench, and weary out the enimie in ≈øuch ≈øort, that hee ≈øhould not bee able to di≈øquiet the be≈øieged, and ≈øo expect vntill the Autumne ≈øhould bee pa≈øt, and than the waters would cau≈øe him to depart of his owne accord, or at the lea≈øtwi≈øe bee con≈øtrained to for≈øake ≈øome quarter or other, by which meanes wee might haue a way opened to bring in Munition, and ≈øoldiers and nece≈ø≈øaries, as much as ≈øhould be required for the deliuerance of the City. Count Henry cannot approue this enterpri≈øe, indeed hee made tryall of ≈øome others, in tho≈øe places which were mo≈øt fortified, and contented him≈øelfe with this conclu≈øion, that the Enemies trenches were not po≈ø≈øible to bee entred. Hauing therefore intended a diuer≈øion of his Army hee leaues the ≈øiege, and ≈øends to hazard the pa≈ø≈øage of the Y≈ø≈øel, by Lucas Cayro, who hauing pa≈ø≈øed happily, hee followed him, and ioynes the Imperiall Army with theirs, which Army was come for our aid and reliefe. And what doth hee than? hee begins to treat with the Burgomai≈øters of Cities, onely to repleni≈øh his owne Coffers, and fami≈øh the faire≈øt and compleate≈øt Army which had beene ≈øeene in a long time, in ≈øtead of demanding vp tho≈øe places where there were neither ≈øoldiers nor munition, and which doubtle≈ø≈øe would haue ≈øurrendred at the very ≈øight of a ≈øtock of a tree, or the ≈ømalle≈øt and ≈øimple≈øt ≈øtroake which could haue beene made at them.

You ≈øhall ob≈øerue, if you plea≈øe, an excu≈øable perfidiou≈øne≈ø≈øe. When Lucas Cayro had pa≈ø≈øed the Y≈ø≈øell. Contrary to the opinion of Count Henry, and that the terrour of an explioct ≈øo newly put in practice, and not fore≈øeeene had a≈øtoni≈øhed all Holland. The Prince of Orange hauing a≈ø≈øembled the whole Councell, and propounded vnto them what had ≈øo lately and vnexpectedly happened, put into deliberation whether the ≈øiege ≈øhould bee ray≈øed yea or no. The aduice and opinion of all the Councell, and each of them was, that the Veluwee being thus occupied and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed vnexpectedly, the Cities of Arnheym, Amersfort, Doesburgh,
Wageningen, Rhenen, and other neare adioyning places about the Veluwee would bee taken without any re≈øi≈øtance at all, and that the gaine and profit which they ≈øhould make of Shertogenbo≈øch could not countervaile nor recompence the lea≈øt of all tho≈øe lo≈ø≈øes, which they ≈øhould ≈øuffer el≈øewhere, if their enimie were permitted to ceaze vpon the very heart of the Country. The Prince of Orange did very much commend the advice of the≈øe Coun≈øellors, and ≈øaid, that verily ≈øome cour≈øe mu≈øt bee taken, if that which they obiected mu≈øt needs fall out ≈øo, but hee could a≈ø≈øure them to the contrary, and that the event would proue otherwi≈øe. And from whom I pray, could he haue this knowledge and a≈ø≈øurance but from Count Henry De Bergh, who in effect neuer made ≈øo much as any ≈øhew of demanding vp any City. Who within his owne view permitted the City Desburgh to be revictualled, and that was the cau≈øe that ≈øome poore Hollanders were executed being Catholicks, becau≈øe they had declared and manife≈øted the intelligence which hee had receiued from them priuately. In a word Shertogenb ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ch was not releiued, and in effect nothing could be expected on his part ≈øince he had engaged him≈øelfe by promi≈øe to his ≈øi≈øters not to re≈øeue the ≈øame.

What water can wa≈øh him cleare from the lo≈ø≈øe of We≈øel, which was taken from vs at the ≈øame time? ≈øeeing that as ≈øoone as euer he heard of the newes, hee kept him≈øelfe ≈øhut vp in his Chamber for 24. houres together, for feare lea≈øt hee ≈øhould bee required to ≈øend help to recouer the ≈øame City; and when as Count John of Na≈ø≈øau hauing intreated him to furni≈øh him with men, to regaine that place, before the open breach where the Enemie entred, was made vp, hee refu≈øed it. The Gouernour of Diden hath ≈øpoken it to Count Iohn of Na≈ø≈øau with his owne mouth that if hee had come to releiue the City of We≈øell any time within fiue dayes after the ≈øame was taken hee might haue entred without any difficulty. If Count Henry had beene an hone≈øt man, wee had fini≈øhed our warre that yeare, and the Catholicke Religion, (with which cloake hee hides his ba≈øene≈ø≈øe, and the blackne≈ø≈øe of his Hypocri≈øie) had neuer ≈øuffered ≈øo much as the ≈øame hath done euer ≈øince.

What wonders hath hee wrought? where are the great exploicts
of his Conque≈øts? Let this al≈øo moreouer bee ≈øpoken for the great ≈øeruices which hee alleageth in Generall. Hee him≈øelfe hath oftentimes avouched, that he neuer hath receiued wound or hurt in the Kings ≈øeruice (notwith≈øtanding that ≈øome Hi≈øtories and report would haue made him beleeue that hee was once hurt in the leg or thigh, in a skirmi≈øh neere vnto Ruremond in the yeare 1598.) which hee attributed to a Mandegloire, or little figure or ≈øhape of a man, which hee ordinarily carried in a ≈ømall box, very durty and foule, which he hath ≈øhewed to more than one per≈øon.

Indeed his ≈øeruices are well knowne, if euer any mans were; hee entred very poore into the ≈øervice of our Princes, and now at this in≈øtant hee is ≈øo rich that he po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth millions. From a particular Hor≈øeman, and meane≈øt of his hou≈øe, hee was advanced to the greate≈øt offices which any ≈øervant of his Maie≈øty could a≈øpire vnto. And therefore hee hath great rea≈øon to ≈øay, that the Nobility is not in that e≈øteeme as they ought to bee; ≈øeeing that the Honours, Offices, and Dignities are ≈øo ill be≈øtowed; and that hee alone doth po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe that, which a dozen others better de≈øeruing than him≈øelfe would e≈øteeme them≈øelues happy to enioy. God bee thanked there are none that are vnprovided, and not one who hath ju≈øt cau≈øe to complaine.

Are they not farre engaged and employed in the hou≈øe, and ≈øervice of their Soueraigne? Doe not they hold the mo≈øt part of the Gouernments? Who doe po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe the principall Offices, and Eccle≈øia≈øticall Dignities but tho≈øe of the Low-Countryes? If the Spani≈øh, whom Count Henry vpbraides to bee the ≈øole Gouernours haue any part in the Government, and charge, it is for to expo≈øe their liues for our pre≈øeruation, and proceeds from the great care which the King hath for our protection. Which this new reformator qualifies with the name of Domination, intending thereby to make the ≈øame odious.

Tho≈øe of the Country in particular, and tho≈øe of other nations, who vnanimou≈øly liue in ≈øervice here, and brotherly one with another, haue their part in the cheife≈øt charges and offices as well as the Spaniards. The Marquis Spinola hath bad the General≈øhip both by Sea and Land; and at this pre≈øent the General≈øhip both
of the Cavallery and Artillerye, are not po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Spani≈øh. Wee haue ≈øeene tho≈øe of the≈øe Countryes reciprocally in the Councels of Spaine, and the managing of the mo≈øt important matters: And wee haue ≈øuch ≈øtill at this pre≈øent. Our di≈øcontented Count Henry contradicts him≈øelfe, hee doth not remember that in his letter full of ≈øedition which hee wrote vnto the Stat ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ of the≈øe Countryes, hee confe≈ø≈øeth that hee was called vpon by the King, to bee imployed in great affaires.

The Nobility than is not in ≈øo ≈ømall e≈øteeme as hee would make the world beleeue, and his complaints are altogether without ground and foundation full of contradictions, ≈øeeing that he him≈øelfe hath beene honoured with the command of being Generall of the Army, when the Spani≈øh, and other Nations haue beene excluded therefrom. It is hee him≈øelfe that hath lo≈øt ≈øome of the Nobility. The Prince of Chimay, and the Baron De Belvoire, who haue beene di≈øplea≈øed at their very death, ≈øeeing the King betrayed by his Monopolies, will one day acou≈øe and reproach him before the throne of God, of the lo≈ø≈øe of twentie thou≈øand good men, which hee cau≈øed to langui≈øh in Mi≈øery, to the end hee might v≈øe the Kings Enemies gently, who did contribute great ≈øummes of money to ≈øati≈øfie his Avarice. The Father Hermanus Hugo, did in the Army reproach him at the very point of death, and could not ≈øurvive the publick Calamity.

Count Frederick his Brother ≈øhall accu≈øe him in like manner & lay as much to his charge, for being ≈øo ≈ølack and remi≈øse, and lo ‚Ä¢
≈øing all occa≈øion of releeuing the mo≈øt Catholick City of Shertogenbo≈øch, which that Generous Cavallier hath formerly deliuered (in the yeare 1604) from the ≈øiege of Graue Maurice, who had blocqued vp the ≈øame. Let therefore Count Henry blame his owne in≈øatiable couetou≈øne≈øse for di≈øorder, and attribute the ill gouerment to him≈øelfe, without the which wee might at this day reioyce in a mo≈øt happy and honourable peace, a≈øsuredly euen ≈øuch a peace which good ≈øubjects ought to wi≈øh vnto their Prince for the reputation of his Crowne.

As for the Commi≈ø≈øion of Ma≈øter of the Field Generall, which hee ≈øaith was conferred vpon him two yeares agoe, by her Highne≈ø≈øe in the name of the Kings Maie≈øty, and which hee is now re≈øolued to exerci≈øe
and execute for the ≈øervice of the Countryes, the pre≈øeruation of the Privilidges, and the vpholding of the H. Catholicke, Apo≈øtolicall and Roman Church. You may thereby ≈øee vnto what a degree, and height of impudency the audaciou≈øne≈øse of this Traitor is come? How doth hee pay and recompence our good and vertuous Prince≈øse with ingratitude? How doth hee accu≈øe her of Conniuance ≈øaying, that hee knowes that ≈øhe wi≈øheth that the affaires went better? And as it were acknowledging the goods deedes, and ≈øupreme honours which hee hath receiued from her extreame goodne≈ø≈øe and bounty, hee hath ≈øo much boldne≈ø≈øe and audacity to take her for a prote trix of his mi≈øchiefe, and ≈øo doth declare him≈øelfe openly to bee guilty, as now hee is proclaimed. To bee guilty of crimen lae≈øae Maie≈øtatis in the highe≈øt degree, and capitall Enemie of the publike re≈øt, and therefore con≈øequently fallen away, and deprived of all his Honours, offices, Dignities, and intere≈øt which hee hitherto hath had in his Maie≈øties ≈øervice.

In the yeare 1484. the Count de Rom ‚Ä¢ nt did by the like practice bare Armes again≈øt the Arch-Duke Maximilian his Lord, & attributing in like manner to him≈øelfe the title of Captaine Generall of the Prince Philip his ≈øonne, hee wrote in this ≈øort to the States generall a≈ø≈øembled in the City of Bruxels, his an≈øwer giuen him was this. That they did not acknowledge him for ≈øuch, but an Enemie of the Prince and of the ≈øtate.

As for the Countryes, in the name of God let him leaue them in peace, for there is no need of forging any innouation, wee need no broiles nor Traitor to trouble our tranquility. The flock would bee in good ca≈øe vnder the clawes of the Wolfe, if our Religion had no better Protector. Oh had but this blacke ≈øoule as much capacity, and ability as hee hath hatred and malice, wee ≈øhould ≈øoone ≈øee a ≈øtrange Religion, and ≈øuch Lawes, that Saturue and
‚Ä¢ up ‚Ä¢ ter would not bee brought in but for them onely. I cannot conceiue how a man that hath no Religion at all: who hath fal≈øified his Faith, and who in the yeare 1621. when hee went before Iulliers, by Te≈øtament written by his owne hand, which hee left to his ≈øi≈øter Anne, did ordaine to bee bu ‚Ä¢ yed or enterred in a prophane place neerer vnto his ≈øi≈øters, will not onely cloake and cover him≈øelfe with a vaile of Religion, but al≈øo counterfeite
him≈øelfe to bee a protector of the Catholike, Apo≈øtolicall, and Romi≈øh.

You deceiue your ≈øelfe Mon≈øieur Count Henry, you mu≈øt not ≈øend your manife≈øtations and declarations into your Government of Geldria, hereof your Con≈øcience is to well knowne there, the City of Stefen≈øwert, which you haue made neutrall to ≈øerue for a retreat vnto the Enemies of the King, and to the Hereticks, and where you haue brought the Mini≈øters to poi≈øon the people and in≈øtruct your Si≈øters Anne, and Charloite, the≈øe ≈øhall te≈øtifie of your carriages, and your ≈øecret behaviour. Doe not you remember that ≈øometimes by chaunce and through forgetfullne≈øse you left a little haereticall prayer booke in high-dutch on a ≈øeate in the Ie≈øuiti≈øh Church at Ruremond. Which booke you called your Haureman? you haue written to Prie≈øts and other per≈øons well qualified, and of diuers Nations, that your ≈øi≈øters were chri≈øtianly decea≈øed, and that their ≈øoules were very happy. In the meane while you know, that they gaue vp the gho≈øt in the Armes of ≈øuch Mini≈øters which you had procured them. Wee know more of your newes than you doe thinke for.

Hee ends his letter with the retreat which hee had made into the City of Liege for the advancement of his de≈ø≈øeyns. Wherein his ≈øubtiltye ill compacted together is failing; for the Deputes of the Prince and States of Liege, not willing to prejudice any way to ≈øo good neighbourhood, haue di≈øclaimed his action by a decree.
‚Ä¢ une the 23. the contents whereof are the≈øe. A declaration publi≈øhed to ≈øhew that his letters and his declaration haue bee ‚Ä¢ e publi≈øhed without any knowledge of theirs or participation, and con≈øent, and that they intend in no wi≈øe to entermeddle with any affaires of the ≈øaid Count Henry. Nay, for their better Iu≈øtification, they haue obliged him by a writing of his owne hand the 25. day of June. That they would haue it manife≈øted. That as hee had publi≈øhed the ≈øaid letters without hauing given notice or asked permi≈ø≈øion of his H ‚Ä¢ of Liege, or the Deputes of his ≈øtates, and how that hee intended not by tho≈øe publications to attempt any thing again≈øt their right, nor envolue their affaires into his actions.

This retreat of his hath beene intended along time, not for the ≈øervice of the Countryes nor Religion; but plotted and combined
with our Enemies. And if it were not, ≈øo how could hee haue had time enough to treate with the King and Princes which in the end of his Letter to the States he affirmes, to bee inclined to contribute their forces for the execution of his de≈øignes? But there are other ≈øufficient proofes: & it is not of a day or two that his trea≈øon hath bin ‚Ä¢ eproched unto him, and hit in his teeth by the brother of the hu≈øband of the ba≈øtard daughter, wee ≈øhall ≈øpeake of that in his due place, it is ≈øufficient for this point to manife≈øt what is mo≈øt true, that before ever the Prince of Orange came to field to march to Venlo, hee had beene to conferre with him in Holland, and did ≈øo within a mile from the City, in the Ca≈øtle of Holtmullen, where al≈øo was the Earle of Culenbergh, his brother in Law, and that before that time he had cau≈øed five Barrels of Silver to bee convayed to Me≈øeycke, there to buy the nece≈øsary provi≈øion for the ≈øiege of Ma≈øtricht, under a colour that they were the Prince of Orange his moneys de≈øtined by him at the retreat of Count of Horne, engaged the Prince of Liege. See there, the≈øe be the good & charitable Offices, which this di≈øsembling Patriot intends to practice for the good of the Countryes. The letter which he ≈øent to the States, was almo≈øt of the ≈øame tenure and contents as that written to her Highne≈øse: we will onely examine the≈øe things which are of note and moment. He ≈øaith that he had given advice that the place of the enemies meeting or rendevons ≈øhould be at Moock neere≈øt of all to his Government. He would ≈øpeake according to knowledge concerning the place, and not without rea≈øon, but hee might know ≈øince it was he that had called the enemy thither. But is ab≈øolutely fal≈øe that hee gave them any advertizement or notice at all, but onely at the very in≈øtant when the enemy arrived.

He propo≈øeth his naturall affection vnto the good of the Countries. He is a ≈øtranger, revengefull, full of ill will and malice, who intends and labours to make a private di≈øcontent & grudge a publike cau≈øe, he ≈øtomacks the Marqui≈øe De Leganes, who hath beene indeed ray≈øed in the≈øe Countries to be a Patriot, him he accu≈øeth imprudently, and unadvi≈øedly of ≈øuch bu≈øine≈øse which he was never acquainted withall, the ≈øaid Marqui≈øe at that time not being intere≈øsed in the matter. If hee thinke him≈øelfe wronged in any thing, it is lawfull for him to right him≈øelfe by an ordinary cour≈øe,
But not to commit ≈øuch a loo≈øene≈øse, and to play the little Tyrant. What have the≈øe Countries to doe with his particular quarels & heart-burning? If his courage had had edges ≈øharpe enough, and wings ≈øwift enough for honour, and that he thought him≈øelfe ≈øo grievou≈øly offended, as he ≈øpeakes of: as oftentimes as hee hath had occa≈øion to ≈øee the Ma ‚Ä¢ qui≈øe Nay more, as often as hee hath ≈øeene him, who hath hindered him from demanding him ≈øatisfaction? As for the Spani≈øh Nation which he complaines doe wi≈øh his death, and that they ≈øhot at his Picture, which hangs neere the Steenport, he hath exceeding great wrong, for if it be true, that the Spaniards be ≈øuch as hee ≈øpeaketh of, they had all of them long ≈øince beene made away, and he who for the pre≈øent ≈øerves for Coun≈øellor, hath oftentimes inculcated the meanes to de≈øtroy them, and ≈øaid that therein hee went in the Kings ≈øervice; But his Oracles ≈øounded alwayes ≈øo little profitable to the King, that no tru≈øt might be given to his per≈øwa≈øions: It hath proved better, to goe a milder way to worke, and to ≈øtrive to redre≈ø≈øe what≈øoever was ami≈ø≈øe by gifts, and employments, than to practi≈øe any ≈øuch extremitie, which the world would never have judged worthy to bee executed, if the proofe had not beene drawne, as now it is by his owne declaration.

It is very pretty that he complaines of the Spani≈øh, becau≈øe they ≈øhot at his Picture: his ≈øpyes would have much a doe to bring ≈øufficient witne≈ø≈øe for the proofe thereof, although (to be true & plaine) he that betrayes his Prince de≈øerves otherge≈ø≈øe puni≈øhment than he that onely exerci≈øeth his trea≈øon again≈øt his picture. It was he, the felon, who ≈øo lately on the 27. of Iune was ≈øo ra≈ø ‚Ä¢ and impudent as might lye in the City of Bruxels, by the patricidious hands of his wicked adhaerents cau≈øed attempt to bee made again≈øt the ≈øacred Image of the King his Lord and good Ma≈øter, by that meanes to endeavour to begin by that execrable fact the fir≈øt exployts of his rebellion. But the contrary of which they intended is happened, and the wicked projects of the≈øe imps prevayled not, for two dayes after the States of Braband not being able any longer to endure the indignity of this abomination, of their owne proper motion, came per≈øonally in publike audience, to the great edification of all that were pre≈øent, and pre≈øented them≈øelves before
the Prince≈ø≈øe, and there renewed ≈øolemnely the Oath of fidelity and allegeance to the King their Prince, and Naturall Lord, & to her Highne≈ø≈øe, declaring that they were ready to take the ≈øame Oath to the Prince of Spaine.

As for tho≈øe Offices and charges which he ≈øayes, are not conferred upon any bat Spaniards. I mu≈øt here needs repeat, that hee him≈øelfe at their conclu≈øion, had the principall of all, but hee hath very ill di≈øcharged him≈øelfe, and I mu≈øt ≈øay that his ingratitude hath neyther bounds nor limits. Wicked ≈øervant as he is, he never ≈øerved but by intere≈øt, and never Prince was more liberall to any man, than our Prince≈ø≈øe haue beene to him. Never did hee march forth with the Armies but in the up≈øhot he obtayned ≈øome ≈øummes of moneys for his particular, and ever received more than any Spaniard, or Lord of the Countrey, be≈øides tho≈øe ≈øecret gratuities and benefites which hee obtayned under hand, whereof hee never made any account but applyed them to his private gaine & profit. He knowes well enough how punctually he cau≈øed all reareges to be payd him downe before ever he would ≈øet one foote on the way to the Palatinate. In a word for that e≈øtate & ≈øub≈øtance which now he hath, he is more obliged than any man in the world for it, and to that King again≈øt whom hee now takes up Armes.

From a meane Soldier hee was made a Captaine of Hor≈øe, afterward Ma≈øter of the Campe, hee was tru≈øted with the City of Oldenzel; afterward with Groll, and at la≈øt hee had the Government of the Province of Geldres, which than was one of the be≈øt and faire≈øt Province of all the Countries, hee hath al≈øo had the generall Government of the Cavallery, and the General≈øhip of the Artillery, he hath commanded the whole Army, and alwayes with retention of the wages of all places and charge which formerly he exerci≈øed; to be ≈øhort, In the yeare 1629. he was by her Highne≈ø≈øe in the name of the King made Generall Ma≈øter of the Campe of the whole Army of his Maje≈øty. Whereunto could his ambition a≈øpire higher unle≈ø≈øe it were to Tyrannie which he now affects at this pre≈øent? Our enemies them≈øelves with whom he hath held corre≈øpondency and wrought his mi≈øchievous practi≈øes a long time have beene a≈øtoni≈øhed many times, that ≈øo many recompences ≈øhould prodigally bee lavi≈øhed and wa≈øted upon one who was
≈øo vnde≈øeruing and demeriting. La≈øt of all, which is more, when the Earle of Stryrum entred into Gueldres with the Enemies troupes, ≈øeeing the County of Montfort, which is worth more in reueneus than twentie thou≈øand Florins, and which the King had given to Count Henry de Bergh, with many other Townes and villages of the Country of Stefens wert, hee could not withhold nor ab≈øtaine from ≈øaying, that hee marvailed much how the King could find in his heart to be≈øtow ≈øo much vpon one of a contrary party. Adding withall, that if he ≈øhould haue ≈øerued the States of Holland, an hundred yeares, hee would not haue beene requited with ≈øuch an honourable reward.

As for his Expre≈ø≈øion. That he invites vs to accept of one of his pa≈ø≈øions, and to take another cour≈øe vnder the gouernment of her Highne≈ø≈øe. Wee thanke him for his good will, and to thanke God that hee hath beene plea≈øed to di≈øcover vnto vs and Enemie, who could ≈øo clo≈øely and covertly hatch and plot our ruine and de≈øtruction, if he had but ≈øo much ayde and conduct, as hee is full of euill motions and intentions. Our wi≈øe Prince≈ø≈øe hath no need of ≈øuch a Tutor, to di≈ø≈øipate and ≈øcatter abroad the Patrimony of the King her Nephew. And de≈øolate and ruinate a Country ≈øo well gouerned, which for many yeares together hath co≈øt his Maie≈øtie all the ri
‚Ä¢ hes of Spaine and the Indyes, and the blood of ≈øo many thou≈øand Spaniards ≈øpilt for the ≈øafety and pre≈øervation of the ≈øame and for the Catholick Faith and Religion.
There remaines yet his Declaration, which is nothing el≈øe but a manife≈øtation of his di≈øcontent, and a profer of entertainment vnto tho≈øe that will bee his followers.

It is very well knowne that he bath moneyes and good ≈øtore of Coine, if hee had no more but what hee hath gotten by the Pa≈ø≈øeports which hee continually ≈øold without cea≈øing, while≈øt the licencyes were ≈øhut, and the traffick and commerce, prohibited and interdicted with the rebellious Provinces. It is al≈øo well known that he hath receiued many gifts & pre≈øents from Princes and tho≈øe people that were neare adioyning neighbours vnto his Government. No, the≈øe things wee are no more ignorant of, than wee are of the monies which hee ≈øtill hath in his hands, for which pence of ≈øiluer hee treacherou≈øly ≈øold his Mai≈øter; but his in≈øatiable couetou≈øne≈ø≈øe would neuer ≈øuffer him to v≈øe his riches
liberally towards tho≈øe which were hone≈øt and good men. There is not one ≈øoldier that knowes him, who doth not al≈øo know the ≈ømall account which he makes of them, and who doth not remember how euilly he hath alwaies intreated them in his goverment, cutting off from them the commodities, which in other places the Country people did not deny them, to extort mo≈øt exo ‚Ä¢ bitant contributions for his owne particular; ≈øo that certainly you may beleeue (my Lords) that the ≈øoldiers will giue no more credency to his declaration than your honours haue done to his letters.

You haue witne≈ø≈øed the condemnation which you haue made, your good zeale toward Religion, your ≈øincere affection to the Prince≈ø≈øe, and your duties in the behalfe of the Countryes. Religion ≈øhall euer bee obliged vnto you, the King ≈øhall euer acknowledge your loyaltye and accept of your fidelity, the Prince≈ø≈øe doth highly e≈øteeme and commend, yea reioyce in your affection towards her, ≈øhee embraceth them, and gives you hearty thankes. And the Countryes ≈øhall ≈øee their owne pre≈øervation by your meane ‚Ä¢ . Doe ≈øo much more for the publick good, that henceforward all tho≈øe that audaciou≈øly and pre≈øumptuou≈øly ≈øhall dare to take part and adioyne them≈øelues to this new Tyrant, or protect his cau≈øe ≈øo vniu≈øt and dete≈øtable, may bee reputed and accounted as fauourers, and complotters of his Rebellion.

As for the re≈øt that concernes the plots practices and diui≈øes of our Enemies remember the co≈øt and charges of the time pa≈øt, that all the Inventions of liberty of con≈øcience which now he pretends, haue not beene invented for any other end but meerely to ruine the beautifull foundation of our Religion, to e≈øtabli≈øh an hundred other new ones, and to corrupt the tenderne≈ø≈øe of our Children by the pernicious examples, and introduction of here≈øie. The≈øe are the wayes & cunning windings which our enemies goe and walke in. The≈øe are the enchanted kindne≈øses which they pre≈øent unto us. Should we have a heart to receive ≈øuch impoy≈øoned gifts, which are profered us by the hand of an enemy? Who ≈øhould then furni≈øh and provide us with Prelates and Prie≈øts, and per≈øons nece≈ø≈øary for our Ceremonies, for the comfort and con≈øolation of our Soules, the ea≈øe and peace of our Con≈øciences? When
our Prelates ≈øhall be decea≈øed, whence ≈øhould wee have new ones bred among≈øt us? What Apo≈øto ‚Ä¢ icall Bulles would authorize them? Who would ≈øet them in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, when our enemies hold this for a maxime and foundation, not to acknowledge the Romi≈øh Church. And la≈øt of all what a≈øsured treaty and contract could we make with our victorious enemies, and their cautions which at this day doe trouble whole Europe, and leave not one corner of the World where the Catholickes are not per≈øecuted eyther by effect, or apprehen≈øion in the expectation of the progre≈øse of Armes, and by the fu
‚Ä¢ our of the Heretique.
